sub_title: Bsc. Organic Chemistry, Chemical Researcher at ProQR
summary:
Phrases which would describe my attitude:

- No pain, No gain.
- Obstacles are temporary and are allowing you to accept the challange and come up with the right solution which would last forever.
- Perspectives, ideas and knowlegde from others are assets gained from experiance. Stay eager to learn from others expertise and experience.

As long as I can remember I had a interest in scientific matters. Because of this reason I chose an education that verifies my interests in classes, which were: Math, Physics, Chemistry and Biology.

Having these interests, a path towards Organic Chemistry was formed. Starting with my first degree as Associate chemical-physical scientist (Analytical Chemistry) and followed up by a prestigious/respectable Bachelor's degree in Organic Chemistry, which was accomplished within 2 and a half years. During my laboratory career, I was allowed to experience GMP, QC, Forensic and R&D laboratories.

While in my Bachalors, affinity for Medicinal Chemistry was developed. This includes matters in Protein/Peptide Chemistry, Synthesis of Small Molecules, MS techniques, HPLC Purifications and Biochemical approaches.

company.name: The Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson

profile_positions.company: The Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson
profile_positions.description:
During my internship at the PQM-FPT departement a job offer came to be at the IPC departement. I was recommended to this offer and maded through the application.

IPC is a departement with a important role. During the production of commercial medicines mid-process analysis are required. The IPC department is mainly responsible for those analysis. For this reason weekend employees are originated.

My responsibilities are:
- Performing OD280, Protein concentration determination.
- Review/Test verification of the OD280 assay.
- Sample handling, an essential role which controls the transfer and assignment of samples from the factory-site to the laboratory-site.
- Monitoring/ordering/deliver of Reference Materials (RM) using Biological Specimen Inventory systems (BSI)
profile_positions.title: Technician, division In Process Control (IPC)

profile_positions.company: The Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson
profile_positions.description:
Being an intern in a pharmaceutical company like Janssen Biologic is a great experience for young scientists.
While experiencing the GMP-environment with all its ins and outs, performing dedicated and specialized assays is part of the daily routine. Those assays includes the following techniques:

- cIEF, capillary Iso Electric Focusing
- cSDS, capillary Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate
- Residual Moisture, Karl Fischer
profile_positions.title: Intern/Jr. Technician, division Product Quality Management- Final Product Testing (PQM-FPT)

profile_positions.description:
My graduation internship was carried out the Leiden University Medical Center (LUMC), department Cell and Chemical Biology (CCB) which was led by Professor Huib Ovaa team.

The laboratory is known as “The ubiquitin system chemistry & dynamics” division. The main field of research is conducted on the Ubiquitin Proteasome System (UPS). Within this group researchers are developing new techniques to profile cellular processes using synthetic ubiquitin (Ub) as scaffold.

The thesis-project was called: “The development of Mass Spectrometry (MS) Ub-SUMO-based tools to identify specific interactors of SUMO-Ub hybrid chains” with my part being the synthesis of these poorly understood hybrid chains using novel synthetic approaches. Understanding those responses of these chains is crucial since these signals play a role in DNA repair, immune responses and regulation of membrane dynamics. The main goal of this project was to identify specific interactors of such hybrid chains, to understand the biological processes that they mediate.

During my Internship, experiance in the following techniques were obtained:
- Organic Chemistry, Including Protein Chemistry and Click Chemistry 
- Shimadzu/Waters HPLC systems
- Biorad NGC - FPLC, SEC system
- Full characterisation NMR (1H, 13C, COSY, HSQC)
- Column Chromatography
- LC-MS
- LC-HR-MS
profile_positions.title: Intern/Chemical Biology & Drug Discovery Researcher in the Ovaa Lab

profile_positions.description:
Durining my internship at the forentic institut, a statement of the company was made clear to me, which was: Focused on truth - Guided by science - For a safer society.
 
The Dutch Forensic Institute was known of investigating traces of crimes. The institute offers highly specialized expertise and is therefore an important link in the criminal law.

The insernship was devided up in parts.
During the first part of my internship, learning about the the company and the rules of drug identification were prioritised. This learning process was mainly achieved by reading documents, learning from experienced researchers, observing and peforming routinely research. The routinely research consisted of the identification of common drugs with the following techniques:
- Global drugs colouring techniques.
- FT-IR.
- GC-MS.
- Microscopy (used for vegetable material). 
My overall drug knowledge was improved and raised to an advanced level.
Thereafter I was allowed to experience the more complex research, the following techniques are experienced:
- GC-FID.
- HS-GC-MS.
- LC-TOF.
My internship ended with writing a successful and neat thesis which provides an important and relevant insights into the market movement of opium law substances, as traded on the streets. The thesis was called Staat-Onderzoek (SO) 'Street-Research in English'. This research was performed on drugs samples coming from all over the Netherlands. Aside showing statistical relevance of drug movement, monitoring unusual substance in drug samples are mapped and identified. The Four most common opium law substances are included in this research which were: cocaine, heroin, amphetamine and MDMA.
profile_positions.title: Intern/Jr. Forensic researcher, division Chemical Physical Traves (CFS), team Narcotics (VM)
